messages.author: Lambros
messages.text: nit: Move this library header before our project's headers?

messages.author: Jamie
messages.text:
On 2011/07/20 02:40:27, Lambros wrote:
> nit: Move this library header before our project's headers?

I know this is against the style guide, but Xlib defines a whole bunch of symbols that might conflict. I think at the moment there aren't any conflicts with these includes, but I didn't want to risk future breakages.

messages.author: Jamie
messages.text:
On 2011/07/20 02:40:27, Lambros wrote:
> nit: s/int/KeyCode (and in .cc file) ?

Done.

messages.author: Lambros
messages.text:
On 2011/07/20 17:44:54, Jamie wrote:
> On 2011/07/20 02:40:27, Lambros wrote:
> > nit: Move this library header before our project's headers?
> 
> I know this is against the style guide, but Xlib defines a whole bunch of
> symbols that might conflict. I think at the moment there aren't any conflicts
> with these includes, but I didn't want to risk future breakages.
I'm not convinced this is a good enough reason to deviate from the style.  You're taking a bet that future conflicts are less likely with one ordering than with another ordering, and it's not clear to me why that's true.

I'd prefer to stick with the style, but if you want to keep it this way, please add a comment explaining why.

messages.author: Jamie
messages.text:
On 2011/07/20 18:43:47, Lambros wrote:
> On 2011/07/20 17:44:54, Jamie wrote:
> > On 2011/07/20 02:40:27, Lambros wrote:
> > > nit: Move this library header before our project's headers?
> > 
> > I know this is against the style guide, but Xlib defines a whole bunch of
> > symbols that might conflict. I think at the moment there aren't any conflicts
> > with these includes, but I didn't want to risk future breakages.
> I'm not convinced this is a good enough reason to deviate from the style. 
> You're taking a bet that future conflicts are less likely with one ordering than
> with another ordering, and it's not clear to me why that's true.
> 
> I'd prefer to stick with the style, but if you want to keep it this way, please
> add a comment explaining why.

I now pre-declare Display to around this, although note that it necessitated using int instead of KeyCode below.

messages.author: Jamie
messages.text:
On 2011/07/20 02:40:27, Lambros wrote:
> nit: Ctrl+Esc or CTRL+ESC ?

Ken specifically capitalised ESC, but having run it by him, he's changed it (and made it Shift+Esc to avoid conflicts on Windows).

messages.author: Lambros
messages.text: nit: This project header should come after the library headers.

messages.author: Lambros
messages.text: nit: Use arraysize() or ARRAYSIZE_UNSAFE() from <base/basictypes.h>

messages.author: Jamie
messages.text:
On 2011/07/20 02:40:27, Lambros wrote:
> nit: This project header should come after the library headers.

That causes conflicts due to the inclusion of Xlib (for Display) in the header file.

messages.author: Jamie
messages.text:
On 2011/07/20 02:40:27, Lambros wrote:
> nit: Use arraysize() or ARRAYSIZE_UNSAFE() from <base/basictypes.h>

Done.

messages.author: Jamie
messages.text:
On 2011/07/20 02:40:27, Lambros wrote:
> nit: s/int/KeySym ?

Done.

messages.author: Lambros
messages.text:
On 2011/07/20 17:44:54, Jamie wrote:
> On 2011/07/20 02:40:27, Lambros wrote:
> > nit: This project header should come after the library headers.
> 
> That causes conflicts due to the inclusion of Xlib (for Display) in the header
> file.
In that case, please could you add a comment before it, and a blank line after it?  It would be good if the comment could explain the source of the conflict, and add a TODO to fix this.
If we're having to re-order our project headers to work around Xlib issues, then we've already exposed too much of Xlib in our headers.  I can maybe look into this if I find time.

messages.author: Jamie
messages.text:
On 2011/07/20 18:43:47, Lambros wrote:
> On 2011/07/20 17:44:54, Jamie wrote:
> > On 2011/07/20 02:40:27, Lambros wrote:
> > > nit: This project header should come after the library headers.
> > 
> > That causes conflicts due to the inclusion of Xlib (for Display) in the header
> > file.
> In that case, please could you add a comment before it, and a blank line after
> it?  It would be good if the comment could explain the source of the conflict,
> and add a TODO to fix this.
> If we're having to re-order our project headers to work around Xlib issues, then
> we've already exposed too much of Xlib in our headers.  I can maybe look into
> this if I find time.

I'ved moved the offending X11 headers to the bottom of the include order and the header for this class no longer depends on Xlib.h.
